Judah Belgrade

Brandeis · Waltham, Ma 02453 · judahbelgrade@brandeis.edu

I'm gonna make cool things! Yay!

My name is Judah Belgrade and I like to think about design and functionality.

Whether that be a paper plate or a computer keyboard, everything has been made to serve a purpose, and how people come up with those ideas fascinate me.

That is why I am here.

Project 1

We're supposed to use three different type of tests to familiarize ourselves with the printers and the problems that could arise when using them.

Name Tag

The first venture
After making multiple layers by accident, oopsie. We tricked it into skipping a layer and just printing it normally. I need to be very careful with the software. It was a waste of time if I didn’t catch it first, but now it looks cool. Yipee. That took longer than expected.
September 3rd 2025

Benchy Boat Stress Test

Less Stressful, more boaty
Easiest thing ever. The Printer took it like a champ. It looks so nice. It works with a lot of details, as it is the one being tested with most of the printers, so it is only natural that it worked out as well as it did.
September 7th 2025

Left Joy Con Grip

Pain in the Left
After making sure I had the right (left) controller, I needed to choose a stabilizer because it couldn’t stay flat on the printing sheet. It seems like the Organic is easiest to remove, but that’s to be seen. Calibrating the printer wasn’t too hard, nor was a change necessary for the nozzle elevation level. So like, hopefully it prints well. After it printed I realized there must've been a better angle to print it on, because the legs of the controller were a pain in the ass to clean off. Maybe I’ll do it again a different day or layer it over with something different to make it come comfortable.
September 10th 2025

Project 2

Make stuff in tincercad and compare it to fusion and then edit a cool model we find online

Tinkercad Ring

Snug as a bug
The Tinkercad program is something I am deeply familiar with from my time in High School. Splicing and stitching shapes together to create larger, more complex creations is fun and a great brain teaser. Especially the simple User Interface. While the selection of shapes might be limiting, that is part of the creation process. Making more shapes out of other shapes is part of how the program's limitations breed endless possibilities.
September 15th 2025

The Tinkercad program is something I am deeply familiar with from my time in High School. Splicing and stitching shapes together to create larger, more complex creations is fun and a great brain teaser. Especially the simple User Interface. While the selection of shapes might be limiting, that is part of the creation process. Making more shapes out of other shapes is part of how the program's limitations breed endless possibilities.
September 15th 2025

First 3DS Stand

rrrrrrRemix!
After searching for a good ten minutes for a project I’d like to remix in Tinkercad and Fusion, I found a DS stand. It props a DS lite on the bottom half and leans it against a support bar that also has prongs to hold the charging cord in place. It also has a place for the actual charger, as well as slots for some DS games. The only problem is I don’t have a DS lite. So I decided to modify it for my New Nintendo 3ds XL, which involves making everything larger. First I looked up measurements for both the DS lite and N3DSXL, and figured out the ratios to increase the length and width of the base, title and notches that would hold the 3ds. But before that I got distracted by trying to cover up the DS logo and replace it with the 3ds logo. That was really difficult. I do not remember why. I think I was making the 3ds logo based on the parts of the DS logo, and then adding a 3D model of the 3 on that specific font. I then needed to hollow out the charger section, as it was not the same charger. So I looked up dimensions and made a hollowing box and made space for it in the old charger box. But after seeing some comments on the forum about it being too big for the Prusa Mini, I decided to separate the charger box from the main build to decrease its length. And then I realized I needed to slice some of the logo, which wasn’t easy and butchered the logo and made me sad. Oh well. I printed it and found some problems. The ridges carrying the 3ds still needed to be expanded, and the charging port was not large enough. These were the main focuses I would take to Fusion.
September 15th 2025

Second 3DS Stand

TAKEN APART!
September 18th 2025
Before I started using Fusion, I split apart the design to its main components in Tinkercad: The Front, The Base, The Left and Right Ridge Stands, The Two Support Prongs that Hold the Charger Cord, and the Charger Box (now with more space inside). So after sending them all individually into Fusion, it took an embarrassingly long amount of time to not only get them all in, but put them all in the same file and unlink each piece so they can be edited. At that point there were some auto recommendations the software provided to fill up unnecessary holes and simplify the general structure. Sadly, I was unable to fix the logo, but each aspect of the creation was made a little larger in the slicing and editing process. I also decided for my sanity to make each piece of the print flat on the board, so I can put it together when it’s done, as by adding the human touch of physical assembly, it’s almost like I am taking part in a third interface for remixing: Reality.

Final Version

PUT IT ALL TOGETHER!
I found some obvious mistakes in my creation, as the grooves that were supposed to hold the 3ds also printed the square of the base under the grooves, so now there’s extra space in between the front, the base, and the grooves. But this was actually a boon, as the grooves aren’t deep enough. So the extra space between the grooves and the base can be used to support the device. I also hot glued all this stuff together. That was fun. Tactile construction is a lot more enjoyable than the digital make-up of the software. Also, if I didn’t print it out in pieces, I wouldn't be able to have improved the design last second. Overall, reality is the best interface, because it’s what you make of it.
September 19th 2025

Project 3

The goal of this project was to solder and make a shell for said object we were soldering a board for, that being a radio. Starting this project meant working in pairs, so I had to make sure to trust my partner. While we both took turns using the solder, as we both wanted experience practicing, it was of the utmost importance to keep our setup organized, unless we would cross paths and damage the radio with the hot solder, or worse, each other.

Soldering the radio

First Contact
Getting the pieces to solder to the board was difficult sometimes, and when we finished in multiple sessions, it still didn't work. Probably an issue with how we constructed it as we had a pretty large nozzle. But we kept our production organized, despite the difficulties with the soldering.
October 16th 2025

Measuring the radio

numbers and numbers
Afterwards, my project partner Steven Nasar and I took measurements of every dimension and protrusion of the radio. That being the buttons, the knob, the radio antenna, the speaker, and the battery, as to make a case for it. That took a while and we did need to take new measurements whenever things didn’t match up. All of it was a constant process of design and redesign.
October 18th 2025

Modeling the radio shell

Smile and Wave boys
Using Tinkercad to do the modeling for the 3D print and the 2D cut, we used the literal one for one measurements and positions of the board, and expanded it for the model to make space for it, as it will not be exact. The inaccuracies of 3D printing need to be accounted for. Not only that, but laser cutting will need to be done in hopes of having a completed project. That involves making the container for the radio piece by piece. First it was a box, and then it will have groves. Yippee. I am tired.
>

Making a Laser Cut for the Radio

That's how the cookie crumbles
First it was a shell that didn’t need to make room for the radio to be inserted in, but rather to be built around the radio. I made this piece by piece, alienating each side of the radio shell model, as to keep the measurements flat. It’s fun! We made it again, but with grooves. They didn't stay in, oh well!

We need to stop now

yup
This stuff took forever because of the holidays, as such we did not have the same amount of time to work on it outside the classroom as expected. When time contraints are planned out for the majority but cannot be worked around by the minority, it requires enginuity not only in hoow to design time, but make a design faster to save it as well. Both me and my partner took time in between moments of stress and overcomplicated schedules to work on the project, but despite that, it lacks all the polish four weeks of work would imply, with the asterisk that it was more like two and a half.

Dunno lol
